div.p: Greetings. I have received everything you sent and I give you my utmost thanks.
I am not sending back yet, as I have not yet communicated with everyone I wanted to; therefore, I will send it back with the next messenger.

It truly pains me that you are not feeling better, and as far as I understand, it is due to the kidney stones, a torment I too suffer from too frequently. However, I hope you will feel better soon and I pray to the Lord for this to happen.
In the meantime, I have not encountered Mr. Diesbach since he returned.
However, Telamonius has told me everything that happened there.

As for your students, I have written to my brother about how they are behaving here. The situation is not so bad; however, they might make it worse with what they think will make it better; namely, they are overconfident because they are from Zurich, and thus they are being disrespectful to my lord and others.

HÃ¶ngger has publicly confessed; he has been punished like anyone else who would do such a thing, if he were the victor. And when the others were sent for and questioned about it, they used some falsehoods, which they were caught in; this has caused them to be held in contempt; otherwise, people would have been satisfied with them. I also could not detect from others that they had to pay for the name of Tigurini.
Dr. Valentinus did not like them, yet he nonetheless did his best with them because they are from Zurich.
But I plead for them; they are otherwise decent and quiet and very diligent in the sermons. I have nothing new now that you do not already have.

Death is breaking out quite strongly again. Our Nivinus is lying ill along with 6 children; Weberus is silenced; Mauritius cannot, and all the burden lies on us remaining, so there is no rest. Therefore, have patience now; I will write more soon.
May God bless you and yours and protect you from all evil. Amen. Bern, August 24, 1565.
May the sons, sons-in-law, friends, and all brothers be well. Yours always, Johannes Haller.
To the most distinguished man, Mr. Heinrich Bullinger, the most faithful pastor of the church in Zurich, my honorable lord and dearest compatriot.
